item.title: TESOL Teaching Statement
item.dc:creator: cc746
item.content:encoded: Teaching Purpose I began learning a second language (Spanish) in middle school, but it wasn’t until my junior year of high school that I really became interested in learning languages. The summer before my junior year, I spent a month in Spain with the family of the exchange student we had hosted the previous summer. While my host family spoke English quite well, they really pushed me to speak Spanish to take advantage of being immersed in the Spanish culture and environment. This experience also encouraged me to add Latin to my high school curriculum, and later move to Milan to study Italian. Now I am a lover of languages; I have collected dictionaries of and dabbled in Irish, Sicilian, Portuguese, Dutch, Thai and recently studied French during a short stay in Montréal, QC, Canada in July 2017. Teaching Style My teaching style is based mostly on the Communicative Approach (1980). This approach appeals to me because it works for everyone and really focuses on effective and efficient communication (listening, speaking, reading, and writing) while keeping culture in mind. I like to use real-world materials, group/pair work, and games to really get students engaged and make learning fun. I want to focus on teaching adults in conversational, college-prep and business English.  With conversational beginners, I will use the Comprehension Approach (1980) to help students become comfortable with listening and understanding English before pushing them to speak, by using visual dictionaries and labels, short simple sentences and observable actions. I also love to incorporate music, art and other forms of creativity from the Affective Humanistic Approach (1970) to allow students to become more fully immersed in language and culture, and engage other parts of the brain so that language is acquired more naturally; it shouldn’t always need to feel like work. These modalities can tap into students’ interests and help them connect with the language in a way that otherwise might not be achieved. With more advanced students, especially those preparing for college and the business world, I also look to the Direct Approach (1910) and use dialogues, conversations and visual aids to simulate real-world situations. I will best meet the needs of my students by being adaptable. Each student is unique and has different needs and desires for learning English. As such, I get to know my students as quickly as possible so that I can adapt my lessons to match their needs and interests. Finally, creating a comfortable, enjoyable, and fun environment is beneficial and motivating to all. I want to teach English to share my love of languages and culture to those who need/want to learn my native language and the American culture. As a lifelong learner of languages, I understand how and why students of English make the mistakes they do, and so I feel this gives me the empathy and appreciation needed to support ESL/EFL students. My short-term teaching goal is to provide a solid foundation of English (spoken, written, comprehension, expression) to meet students’ immediate goals, and the tools to continue their English language development to more advanced levels. My long-term goal is to encourage students to become lifelong learners and to seek new knowledge. To learn a new language and culture is to gain a new perspective on life and humanity. Teaching Techniques I use several teaching techniques in my classes. As I have learned through Toastmasters Intl., it is important to grab the audience’s attention from the very beginning. So, I like to start each class with a story, music, current event, or interesting discussion to get students primed for the day’s lesson.  I also like to humor and warm language to keep students engaged throughout the lesson. As I have mentioned previously, it’s important to me to get to know my students so that I can weave their backgrounds, experience, interests and desires into lessons as appropriate. Students learn faster and remember more when they can cognitively, emotionally and socially connect with learning material. Another technique I have borrowed from my experience with Toastmasters, is to set the expectation that the classroom is a safe and encouraging space so that students feel comfortable to take risks and make mistakes. I try to employ the 80 (practice) / 20 (teaching) rule as much as possible because, as I know from my personal language acquisition experiences, it’s imperative to practice, practice, practice and then practice some more. I find guided practice and independent practice (in pairs and alone) works well and gives me the opportunity to listen and provide feedback individually. I do offer quizzes and short tests to give me a sense of what I need to review, and to provide the students a sense of how much they have really internalized.

item.title: Curriculum Vitae
item.dc:creator: cc746
item.content:encoded:
Research and Teaching Interests

ESL/EFL, Computer-assisted language learning, Applied linguistics, Educational technologies, Online learning, Project-based learning, Game-based learning, learning analytics and assessment

Education

ARIZONA STATE UNIVERSITY - GLOBAL LAUNCH, online Certificate, TESOL, 2018 Teaching Practicum: Bangkok, Thailand Nov 2018

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, Baltimore, MD Master of Business Administration, Competitive Intelligence, 2008

BRYANT UNIVERSITY - EXECUTIVE DEVELOPMENT CENTER, Smithfield, RI Certificate, Business Analysis (IIBA endorsed), 2010 Certificate, Web Developer Technology, 2001

UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT, Storrs, CT Bachelor of Arts, Psychology, 1998 Certificate, Criminal Justice, 1998 ~ Golden Key International Honour Society, ~ Psi Chi National Honor Society in Psychology, 1997

Professional Experience

YALE UNIVERSITY, New Haven, CT, 2008 – Present Program Manager, Training, Yale Center for Research Computing, 2019 – Present Responsible for the day-to-day management of the YCRC skills-based training program, and the advancement and growth of the program.

Assistant Director, Educational Technology, Yale Center for Teaching and Learning, 2016 – 2019 Responsible for support and collaboration with faculty to migrate courses and project sites from the legacy learning management system (Sakai) to the new learning management system (Canvas), and managing web decommissioning projects.

Project and Portfolio Manager, Campus Technology Services, ITS, 2014 – 2016 Led cross-functional efforts in Campus Technology Services to identify, recommend, and implement initiatives that supported Continual Service Improvement (CSI) efforts. Assisted Associate CIO with operations and strategic management.

Project Manager / Business Analyst, IT Service Management, ITS, 2013 – 2014 Managed scope, resources, schedule, and budget for an IT service management migration/implementation project with a budget of ~$300K. Managed a project team of employees and consultants in the office of CIO.

Project Manager, Center for Media and Instructional Innovation, ITS, 2010 – 2012 Drove content production and execution of special projects to ensure successful completion of Open Yale Courses. Led data analysis and quality assurance/control efforts. Recruited, trained, and managed a part-time staff of 10; directed vendor relationships. The project was named 1 of “The 50 Best Websites of 2011” by TIME, August 2011; designated 1 of “38 Incredibly Useful Sites” by PC World, October 2011.

Web Project Manager / Analyst, Yale College Dean’s Office, 2008 – 2010 Directed development life cycle and maintenance of numerous website projects for over 40 clients within Yale College. Served as functional lead for Dean’s Office on several academic and administrative web application projects, as well as primary support and training person for web systems.

MARIO NEGRI INSTITUTE FOR PHARMACOLOGICAL RESEARCH, Milan, Italy, 2007 – 2008 Informatics Research Fellow, Italian Cochrane Center Maintained web application and database of clinical trial related to continuing education. Directed new web-based projects. Provided copyediting support and translation between English and Italian.

JOHNS HOPKINS BLOOMBERG SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH, Baltimore, MD, 2005 – 2007 BROWN UNIVERSITY MEDICAL SCHOOL, Providence, RI, 2004 – 2005 Web Developer / Systems Administrator / Database Analyst, Center for Clinical Trials, US Cochrane Center Spearheaded full development life cycle and maintenance of web projects, including 4 websites, 2 web database applications, and 3 e-learning courses. Maintained network, servers, and databases, and provided technical assistance to faculty and staff.

Research Experience

UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT, Storrs, CT 1996 – 1998 Research Assistant, Department of Psychology, 1998 Article research, data entry, manuscript preparation for Child Hypnosis Literature Review. Supervisor: Len Milling, Ph.D. (Research team of Irving Kirsch, Ph.D.) ~ Milling, L.S., & Costantino, C.A. (April 2000). Clinical Hypnosis with Children: First Steps Towards Empirical Validation. International Journal of Clinical and Experimental Hypnosis, 48, 2.

Research Assistant, Department of Psychology, 1997 Executed experiments with human participants related to hypnosis for the Placebo Pain Study (Hypnotic enhancement of cognitive-behavioral interventions for pain: An analogue treatment study). Supervisor: Len Milling, Ph.D. 9 hours/week.

Research Assistant, Department of Psychology, 1996 Executed experiments with human participants related to hypnosis for the Cognitive Load Study. Supervisor: Cheryl A. Burgess, Ph.D. 9 hours/week.

Teaching Experience

YALE UNIVERSITY, New Haven, CT, Instructor / Trainer Canvas workshop series for faculty assistants, Yale Law School, June - July 2018 Working Women's Network, Speaking with Confidence series, November 2017 Writing for the Web workshop, Yale College Dean's Office, 2009

BRYANT UNIVERSITY - Executive Development Center, Smithfield, RI, 2002 Tutor / Substitute Instructor – Web Developer Certificate Program Assisted students with assignments and class projects. Reinforced programming ideas and skills, especially HTML, JavaScript, PERL / CGI programming.

STAMFORD PUBLIC SCHOOLS, Stamford, CT, 1999 – 2000 Substitute Teacher – Grades 1-6, General & Special Education Implemented lesson plans, supervised students, and interacted with school administration.

LONG LANE SCHOOL – Connecticut Department of Children and Families, Middletown, CT, 1998 Teacher Assistant / Tutor (Student Intern) Assisted classroom special/general education teacher, tutored students one-on-one, gathered statistical clinical data for institutional reports, attended meetings/workshops with clinical staff and interns. Supervisor: Patrick Russolillo, Ph.D., 120 hours.

NORTH WINDHAM ELEMENTARY SCHOOL, Windham, CT,  1997 Special Education Assistant (Student Intern) Assisted resource room teacher with instruction and homework tutoring for third- and fourth-grade students with learning disabilities. Served as an unofficial substitute teacher for the resource room. Supervisor: Maureen Ryan, 60 hours.

Awards & Certifications

Advanced Leadership Bronze Award – Toastmasters International, 2016 Competent Leadership Award – Toastmasters International, 2016 Competent Communicator Award – Toastmasters International, 2016 Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) v3 Foundations Certification, APM Group Ltd., 2012 Project Management Professional Certification (PMP), Project Management Institute, 2012

Professional Memberships

International Society for Technology in Education (ISTE), 2018 – 2019 TESOL International Association, 2018 – 2019 Project Management Institute (PMI), 2012 – 2019

Volunteer Experience

Toastmasters International Vice President, Education, Yale Toastmasters Club #820, 2017 – 2019 Pathways Guide and Ambassador for District 53, 2018 President, Yale Toastmasters Club #820, 2015– 2016

Special Olympics Connecticut Unified Partner, Tennis and Volleyball, SOCT Central Shoreline, 2017 – 2018 Gymnastics Competition Director, Special Olympics Connecticut, 2015 – 2018 Local Coordinator, CT Tumblers, 2010 – 2018 Gymnastics Coach, CT Tumblers, 1989 – 2018

item.title: About Me
item.dc:creator: cc746
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_49" align="alignright" width="244"] Christine A. Costantino[/caption] I've been involved in higher education for 25 years as a student, technologist, and project manager. After earning a B.A in psychology from the University of Connecticut, I left higher education to pursue a career in client services, until I discovered the World Wide Web and what its technologies can achieve. I returned to school to study web design and development at Bryant  College, and thus began my new career as a Web developer. After getting a few years of experience and expanding my technology prowess, I found my way back into higher education as a technologist for the Center for Clinical Trials at Brown University. I am currently an Assistant Director of Educational Technology in the Center for Teaching and Learning at Yale, where I support faculty with Canvas, and manage pilots and web projects. I am applying to doctoral programs in educational technology and plan to embark on research and teaching in higher education.

item.title: Projects
item.dc:creator: cc746
item.content:encoded: Open Yale Courses provides free and open access to a selection of introductory courses taught by distinguished teachers and scholars at Yale University. The aim of the project is to expand access to educational materials for all who wish to learn. Dr. Cochrane presented Cochrane evidence in a memorable fictional story, while corresponding multiple-choice questions provide users with the opportunity to explore and understand the clinical applicability of a Cochrane Review. Dr Cochrane transforms passive reading of a Cochrane Review into a more interactive learning experience to improve the understanding of Cochrane Systematic Reviews and change professional behaviour.
